_prev_prog_3.EquipmentTested: Valve maintenance on D4 - Low Temp Recirculator
_prev_prog_3.Description:
Ktaft Heinz San Diego is in compliance with the OSHA Standard 29CFR 1910.119, Process Safety Management for Highly Hazardous Chemicals.



Administrative and Engineering controls in place that would mitigate or reduce the possibility of an accidental release of ammonia.



* Ammonia detection control system sets off local audible alarms and activates room ventilation systems.



* Detection control system will also auto telephone dial key facility personnel in the event of leak detection.



* High and low level switches/alarms and written operating procedures prevent abnormal, or hazardous operating conditions within the pressure vessels and remaining refrigeration system.



* Safety relief valves are configured to all pressure vessels, condensers and compressor oil separators to eliminate the potential of over pressurization of those associated pieces of equipment.  The safety relief  valves discharge into a dispersion tank in the event of over-pressurization.



* Refrigeration operators are on duty 24 hours a day, seven days a week.



* Operators make daily periodic rounds and maintain computer log entries to track equipment status.



* Periodic maintenance program is in place to ensure the entire refrigeration system is maintained in optimum operational and mechanical.

_emerg_resp.CoordinatingAgencyName: County of San Diego HazMat Division

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
A.  Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies



Kraft Heinz - San Diego is dedicated to operation of a safe facility for is employees and neighboring community.  A safety committee has been established that is responsible for the implementation of the safety program and an Emergency Response Plan.  This includes safe operation of the ammonia refrigeration system.  Kraft Heinz - San Diego has prepared risk and safety programs to ensure safe handling of the ammonia in the refrigeration system.  Prior to starting operations in 1997, Kraft Heinz - San Diego conducted the following technical studies to identify potential hazards and the appropriate mitigation measures: Process Hazard Analysis, a Hazard Assessment, and a Seismic Assessment.  In addition, Kraft Heinz - San Diego prepared a Risk Management Prevention Program (RMPP) prior to startup of the ammonia refrigeration system.





B.  Stationary Source and Regulated Substance



The Kraft Heinz - San Diego facility is located at 7878 Airway Road in San Diego, California.  The facility started operations at this location in April 1997.  The ammonia refrigeration system is a closed system that cycles the refrigerant, or ammonia, from liquid to gas and back again.  The system, consisting of piping, valves, and process equipment, cycles ammonia through various physical states (high pressure liquid, low pressure liquid, low pressure vapor, high pressure vapor, then back to high pressure liquid) in order to provide refrigeration for product and process equipment.





C.  Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps



Administrative Measures



Kraft Heinz - San Diego has prepared management programs for compliance with the Process Safety Management (PSM) and Risk Management Program (RMP) regulations.  These management programs include, but are not limited to, operating procedures, mechanical integrity, incident investigation, management of change, contractor safety,

and emergency response.  In addition, the facility has conducted studies to identify potential hazards associated with the ammonia refrigeration system and set up a structure to ensure that recommendations from these studies are addressed.



Kraft Heinz - San Diego personnel circulate throughout the plant, taking note of unusual conditions in any portion of the system 24 hours per day.  If a leak is detected or observed by any Kraft Heinz - San Diego employee, it is immediately reported to the on shift refrigeration engineer.  Action is promptly taken to mitigate the leak so normal operations can resume.



Engineering Measures



The ammonia refrigeration system has several monitoring and sensing devices.  These devices will activate alarms when conditions vary beyond designated limits.  The alarms are indicated on local instrumentation panels, and remote alarms at the facility.  Some alarms will be responded to manually while others are interlocked to another device.  The ammonia refrigeration system at the facility is controlled and monitored using the following: 



Process indicators and alarms

Inspections

Preventative Maintenance

Personnel training

Safety Meetings

Incident Investigations

Ammonia Gas Sensors



D.  Five Year Accident History



The facility started operations in April, 1997.  Since that time, there have been no reportable release or near-misses associated with the ammonia refrigeration system.



E.  Emergency Response



Kraft Heinz - San Diego has an Emergency Response Plan that includes requirements, for postings, reporting emergencies, evacuation procedures / routes (including re-entry and accountability), communications, rescue duties, etc.  In addition, the refrigeration personnel are current on all HAZWOPER training including 40 hour HAZWOPER Operations Level training.  An emergency response shutdown procedure for the ammonia refrigeration system has been incorporated in to the Emergency Response Plan.



F.  Planned Changes to Im

prove Safety



All refrigeration technicians are 40 hr. HAZWOPER certified with all associated respiratory protection certifications, and will remain up to date on a continual basis at this level of certification.  The plant evaluates recommendations from audits, Mechanical Integrity (MI) inspections, and PHAs in a timely manner and implements the recommendations that will reduce the possibility of a release and/or mitigate the consequences of an unintentional release.
